content.description: Sit start matched on the low horizontal. Right hand is a decent slopey sidepull, lefthand is just left on a bad slimper. Smear some feet and make a hard lock-off up to a tres petite crystal before moving the feet and making a desperate lurp for a jug sidepull found near the top of the arete. Topout in easier terrain.
content.location: This climb is found just right of the large tree. Sit start matched on the low horizontal.

content.description: Sit-start with both hands in a low horizontal slot found in the middle of the boulder. Underneath the nose feature of the boulder. Pull-on with some good feet and move out left to a tricky hold before smacking with the right hand to a nice positive flat jug. From here make a long reach to the lip and top out on positive holds.
content.location: This climb starts in the middle of the large boulder.

content.description: Sit-start matched on the lip on the far left side of the boulder. Pull-on with some funky foot smears and head out right traversing the lip of the boulder. The handholds and footholds improve around the center of the boulder and then the jugs run out and are replaced with a series of bad slopers.  Continue the traverse on the slopers until you end up just left of a large tree. Throw up a high foot and lunge with the left hand for a large sidepull feature found on top of the boulder, from here roll over the lip to complete the long climb.
content.protection: Varies. a lot of distance is covered, but the hardest sequences are at the beginning and the end. 1.5-5 pads and a spotter of two.
content.location: This problem is found on the far left side of the downhill face on the "Threshold Boulder".

climbs.name: The Little Tree Frog Who Could

content.description: Stand start with a left hand sidepull undercling and a right hand gaston/ undercling pinch feature above your head. Pull into the shallow scoop and fall into a left hand rail before popping for the lip. A few moves right lead to buckets for a topout. A bit funky and a bit of a puzzle, but fun!
content.location: This problem is found between "Millenium Traverse" and "Tiny the Stone Giant". Its starts right above the small boulder that is lodged underneath the "Threshold Boulder".

content.description: Squat start to the left of the large tree with a pair of textured slopers. Pull onto the wall and move up right hand to a nice positive slot in the horizontal. From here a tricky sequence gains a bad left-hand undercling which then leads to a powerful smack for the lip.
content.location: Just left of the big tree. Both hands on the slopey horizontal shelf feature.

content.description: Squat Start with a left-hand crimp sidepull flake and a textured sloper for the right hand. Find a foot and make a hard lock-off up to a slopey horizontal just right of the bird's nest. From here figure out where to get your feet and your other hand before moving out left to a jug slot. From here reach up to encounter the slopey lip. Move left to improving holds or move back right.
content.protection: 1 or 2 pads. the landing is great.
content.location: This problem is found just right of the middle of the boulder, directly under the bird's nest on the obvious sidepull flake and the well chalked right-hand sloper.

climbs.name: The Adventures of Frog and Toad

content.description: Sit start with a sloping left hand hold and a small low right hand horizontal crystal crimp. Find a foot and make a hard smack up to a bad Sloper, from here figure out how to lock-off and reach up lefty to the slot-like sloper. From here figure out how to make it to the top and mantle.
content.location: This problem is found in the middle of the boulder. It uses the right hand start hold of "Frog and Toad" except for the left-hand. The start is a bit low to the ground and a good foot is found far left.

content.description:
This is a large elongated boulder found when traveling from the Movie Gallery Area to the Mammoth Rock Area.    This boulder is quite large and resembles a stone face, or perhaps a frog, depending on your imagination and creativity. The block separates the Mammoth Rock Area from the Movie Gallery, hence how it obtained its name.  

  The boulder has a handful of climbs varying in grades and difficulty and provides the climber with an easy accessible warm-up and project location.
